column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Conventional plant breeding has been efficient in increasing the yield of most major crops , especially under favorable environments .
#Text=For example , in the USA , maize yields increased by more than five-fold since 1930 , mainly due to the development of uniform hybrid varieties .
#Text=However , conventional plant breeding was less successful in traditional low-input or organic farming systems in which more severe stress conditions are experienced .

#Text=In this context , participatory plant breeding ( PPB ) programs are arising worldwide as an alternative solution to meet the needs of small-scale farmers normally overlooked by conventional breeding .
#Text=Participatory breeding differs from conventional breeding mainly on the active participation of other actors besides breeders , such as farmers and/or consumers .

#Text=Portugal was one of the first European countries to adopt maize more than five centuries ago , and is characterized by its great diversity of historical maize populations that can still be found under cultivation .

#Text=In this way , Portuguese maize populations ( Open-Pollinated Varieties — OPVs ) are still evolving and adapting both to the local environment and human uses , namely , to bread production ( ‘ breadability ’ ) .

#Text=To answer the needs of the Portuguese farmers concerning their maize populations ( yield , biotic stress resistance , ‘ breadability ’ , intercropping systems ) , a successful long-term maize PPB program has been running in Portugal since 1984 .

#Text=As part of this program , farmers are encouraged to add simple , low-cost population improvement methodologies to their selection criteria , increasing its efficiency , and allowing them to optimize the use of their own maize populations .

#Text=Maize populations are subject to stratified mass selection with two parental ( male and female ) controls at farmers ’ fields , in a breeder and farmer partnership , with the farmer establishing the breeding objectives .

#Text=Selection takes place not only after harvesting , at the storage facilities ( considering ear morphological traits ) as traditionally applied by the farmer , but also during crop growing before harvest ( considering plant architecture ideotype , root and stalk quality traits ) .
#Text=Several improved OPVs were generated by this PPB program .
#Text=The farmer ’s motivation and time availability/field

#Text=dimensions ( the bigger the field , the larger amount of time needed for stratified selection ) seem to be the two main limitations for the successful implementation of this participatory approach .
#Text=Reliable , low-cost , fast and easy-to-use selection tools are needed to attract farmers to these participatory breeding approaches .
#Text=This PPB program was recently extended to other Portuguese maize OPVs production areas and to organic production systems .
#Text=Both Portuguese and foreign farmers are increasingly concerned with climate change impacts .
#Text=Indeed , the probability of more severe and persistent droughts may increase especially in areas such as the Mediterranean basin .
#Text=The expected global average annual maize yield loss rate due to drought is about 19 % , being the Iberian Peninsula among the areas with the highest maize drought risk .
#Text=Maize is a crop susceptible to drought , and flowering is the most critical period .
#Text=Irrigation helps to guarantee yield and quality under dry and warm climates , and it has expanded worldwide namely in Portugal , allowing higher yields with for example hybrid varieties .
#Text=However , irrigation poses increasing pressure on the available water resources in dry regions such as the Mediterranean .
#Text=Therefore , breeding for higher crop tolerance to drought is imperative for modern agriculture and horticulture in dry and warm areas and for low-input farming systems .

#Text=Incorporation of tolerance/resistance to drought is becoming an important selection objective of ongoing PPB programs and implies the existence of sources of tolerance/resistance traits and adequate and feasible phenotyping approaches and related technologies .
#Text=Lower water requirements of some Portuguese maize landraces are among the major reasons given by Portuguese farmers to keep on producing them instead of hybrid varieties .
#Text=Therefore , traditional maize landraces can be a potential source of genes to develop maize varieties better adapted to drought .
#Text=In addition , the Portuguese maize OPVs have considerable high levels of inter and intra molecular genetic diversity which allows agronomical improvement .

#Text=However , detailed morphological and eco-physiological studies to evaluate their diversity of response to drought are limited and few field studies using this national germplasm have been performed .
#Text=Selecting for drought tolerance/resistance based on yield is a complicated task due to the complex nature of the trait and its low heritability .
#Text=The task becomes particularly complex for participatory breeding approaches in which selection tools are to be applied directly by farmers .
